### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The kids had been having fun all day, there was now a what? Choices:  A: wild ride B: need for rest C: a massive bear D: playing marbles E: constructing<n>Output:		The kids were overworked, so they had a <<<<<<<<<<<<<< rest>>>>>>>>>>>>> rest<n><n>Input:Which of these has the least number of parts? Choices: 1. A: a tiger 2. B: a pig 3. C: a pig in 4. a pig pen 5. D: a pumpkin 6. E: a turtle 7. F: a turtle in a pig pen<n>Output: 1 is the one with the least parts because <<<<<<<<<<<A: a tiger>>>>>>>>>> has a pig.<n>It has the least number of things because <<<<<<<<A: a tiger, a pig>>>>>>>>> has a turtle.<n>2 is the turtle in the pig pen.<n>3 and 7 are incorrect because there are six things mentioned.<n>4 is also incorrect because a pig pen and a turtle are still many things.<n>5 is also incorrect because there are still four turtles mentioned.<n>6 is false because a turtle is only 1 part.<n>Therefore, 1 is true.<n><n>###Instruction:Answer the following questions in the comments below<n>-What was the best day of your life and how did you spend it?<n>-What is/are your hobby/hobbies?<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Choices:  A: pocket B: office supply store C: friend's house D: desk drawer E: city hall<n>Output:		The choices for the pen, other than C, form a sequence or number pattern: A-C-A to E-A-C-A-B-C.<n>Since the choices alternate between A and C until we get to E, select the last pair of letters (B and C), which is E-C-B. Then, select the second to last choice (A-C-A). In other words, pen = (C-B) = CBA<n>So the final answer should be a Pen<n><n>Input:How many candles does Ms. Field have on her birthday cake? Choices:  a) 3 b) 4 c) 5 d) 6 e) 7<n>Output: 42 candles for Lydia Moss Field's birthday<n>Since 4 candles 42=42/4=10, the final answer should be 10 candles<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. A prime number greater than 2 can’t have any divisors aside from 1 and itself. So 3.<n><n>1, 2, 4, and 16 are divisibles by 2. So, 3 is the smallest.<n>But 7 is also a prime. Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n>Output:		The correct answer is Choice E: they help people, Computers, when combined with the appropriate applications and people, help people to solve their problems <n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the questions based on the following pictures.<n><n>**Picture 1**<n>*This is the first picture<n>*<n><n>**Picture 2**<n>*This is another picture<n>*<n><n>### Instructions: Answer each of the following questions accordingly<n><n>*Question 1*: What is the sum of all the cards?<n>*Answer 1*: It is A and B. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The star had 4 rocky planets and 4 gaseous planets orbiting it, what was it part of Choices:  A: hollywood B: night sky C: constellation D: aliens E: solar system<n>Output:		The galaxy was part of the solar system.<n><n>Input:The planets closest to earth are the inner planets Choices: 1: venus 2: mercury 3: mars 4: jupiter<n> Output: The closest planet to earth is venus.<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:His day at the office was nearing an end, he went to the start menu on his computer to do what? Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n>Output:		All of the choices listed above are reasons to power down a computer. Thus, the option is E:Reason exists<n><n>Example:<n><br /> <n>Input:The computer powered off.What event happened?<br /><n><table><n>   <tr><n>      <td>A</td><n>      <td></td><n>      <th align=right>A&nbsp;</th><n>      <td>&nbsp;off</td><n>   </tr><n>   <tr id="A"><n>      <td>B</td><n>      </tr><n>   </table><n>   <dl id="A"><n>     <dt>B</dt><n>      <dd class="dd-alternate"><n>       <div class="dd-item"><n>            <div class="dds"><n>               <i class="fa fa-remove"> </i><n>            </div><n>            <div class="/dds"><n>               Windows shut<n>            </div>   <n>         </div><n>         <div><n>            <img src="https://github.com/HackHands/HackHands-BootCamp/blob/master/images/HackHandsBootCamp_2018/1964.jpg" /><n>         </div>       <n>      </dd><n>       <dt>C</dt><n>      </dl><n>   <span class="red-box-code"><n>              C: shut down<n>       </span><n>   <ul id="Reasons_for_the_computer_going_off_and_then_coming_on"><n>      <li>The computer shut down normally. For example, when you tell it to shut down from your desktop or when the computer's battery runs out of power. Note: In Windows 8 and Windows RT, the computer also shuts down automatically after you set a specified amount of idle time.</li><n>   </ul><n>   <ul><n>      <li class="a">The power light turns on, and then the computer has an unexpected shutdown. Or, the light turns off.</li><n>   <td></td>   </tr><n></table><n><table><n>  <tr><n>   <td>A</th><n>   <td class="a "></td><n>   <th
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:If something is obtuse, what couldn't it be? Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n>Output:		A:bright B:correct C:acute D:pointed<n>E:clear<n>An obtuse angle is one of more than 90° and less than 180°. Thus, acute angles are those between 30° and 90°, and right angles are 90°.<n>So the final 3 answer is C: Acute or B: Correct<n><n>Input:If an object is rectangular with a square base, how are its dimensions usually related? Choices: 1) length/2, width/2 2) length/1 - width 1/2 3) length/1, width/1 3) length/2, 2, width width/2<n>Output:Length/2, width/1Length/2. width/1, length/1<n>The dimensions are related so that both the perimeter and area are equal to the product of each dimension.The perimeter of an object is just the length of that object, whereas the area of an object is the number of square units contained in it.The perimeter is 2 + 2 = 4 since a rectangle has four sides. The area is 2 × 2 = 4. Thus, perimeter is equal to area, which means that perimeter is two-dimensional and area is one-dimensional. If rectangle, the length and width are equal to the diagonal, length, and width. Thus, area is equal to, and perimeter is also equal to.<n>So the final two answer is Length/2, width/ 1.<n>Length/2, width /2, width/2.<n>Length/2. width /2 width/2

Then, 3 months are 3 * 30 = 90 days. The total hours are 316 + 90 = 406 hours in total.<n><n>Question E2: Why is the moon never higher than directly overhead?<n>Answer: It's because of the fact that the moon is orbiting the Earth and is near the sun. So it never moves far enough to be higher than directly overhead.<n><n>Question E3: Why is the sun never higher than directly overhead when it's low in the sky?<n>Answer: The sun is moving further from the orbit of the earth so it never gets high enough to be higher than high than directly overhead.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Reaching advantage position in a competitin puts me in what position as compared to others? Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n>Output:		 A is upper hand  B is higher position  C is advantage position  D is all above.  E Is skill<n>So the answer is advantage position<n><n>Input: The teacher has 1/5  of  her  class  attend  after-school  activity.  Which  of  the  choice  shows  the  ratio  represented  by  the statement?<n>Output: The question needs a variable X: The answer is ________ of X (or) X/15 of X.<n>X/15 is 1/3.<n>So the answer is 1/3<n><n>input:Which of the following is not a ratio?<n> Choices : 15% of 5 7/4 of 5  3/5 of 8, 1/5 of 2<n> Output: The answer will not be given<n><n><n>input: Which of the following shows equivalent ratios? Choices: 4/5, 2/3 <n>Output: 2/3 is equivalent ratio to 4/5<n><n>input: What are equivalent ratios of the following pair of ratios? Choice of a/b: 1/2 2/3, 4/5 5/7, 5 3, 25 3 <n>Output : b/a =5/7<n>b/a =5:7<n>a/b= 25:3<n><n><n>input: If the area of a square is 5/4 times the area of a rectangle how is this a special case of the Pythagorean Theorem<n>Output: The Pythagorean theorem is a2+b2=c2 where a and b are the sides of the triangle and c is the hypotenuse<n><n>input:The diagram of a rectangular field is shown. The width of the field is 3 more than 2/5 of the length.<n>Determine the length of the fence that encloses the field.<n>Output: The diagonal of a rectangle is given by d=2(s1+s2)  where d is the length of the diagonal s1 is the length s2 is the width<n>We need length L fence is perpendicular to the length and the length of the fense is W<n>In triangle LMN LM<n>MN||MX||MN<n>

How can I do it? <n><n><n>    #!/bin/bash<n>    a=1<n>    #b=2<n><n>    IFS=$'\n'<n>    while IFS= read x; do<n>        b=$(( b+1 ))<n>        echo "$a:$b"<n>    done < choices.txt<n>    a=1 #reset<n><n>### Instruction:"Lemonade Stand"<n>In a lemonade stand on a hot summer day 8,000 gallons of lemonade  were served with a total value of $90,000. How many feet does the new chair place between the two chairs that are now farthest apart?<n><n>Output:The new chair is directly between the two farthest chairs, so the new distance between the two farthests chairs is <<4'-2'-3'-2'5'-4'>>4'-2'-3/-2'\begin{array}\\5\end{array}=1' So the final answer choice is B 1 ft.<n><n>Input: Mr. Winslow is a very talented painter. His friend asked him to paint a house on his lot. "All painters know that light colors show up better on light houses and dark colors show up better on dark houses, isn't that right?" I should paint all of this."<n>The Friend replied "But Mr. Winslow, are you really talking about the house?"<n>The Painter replied "Well, no - I'm talking about a very old man who sits around a lot."<n><n>Question: What color would you paint Mr. Winslow?<n><n>Output: This quote is about a very old man (Mr. Winslow) whose wall is white and a red roof. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:If I have a forgiving attitude toward someone, what do they receive? Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n>Output:		A person who has forgiveness in his heart for another is one who desires to redeem the other, that is, to save him from eternal destruction and to secure his salvation.<n><n><n>Input:How old is the computer? Choices: 1. twenty 2. five 3. thirty 4. five hundred twenty<n>Output: One can use computers more than 30 years.<n>Five twenty can be interpreted as 12122 x 4 = <<12122*4=4848>>4848 so the final answer is 4848<n><n>#### Instructed:What two two digit numbers add up to eleven?<n><n>Output: Choices C and D, (9 + 2 = 11)<n>So the final answer to the question to be two 2-2digit numbers 9, and 2<n><n>#### Instructor:Is Mary a younger sister than Alice, but is not younger than Tim? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Where is one likely to hear a harpsichord? Choices:  A: make noise B: band C: museum D: concert hall E: rubber band<n>Output:		One would be likely to hear a harpichord in a concert hall, so the correct choice is E.<n><n>Input:You can make 50 dimes by changing 25 quarters into dimes and by making change. How can you make 75 dimes from 25 quarters?<n>Output:The correct answer is to change 50 dimes to 75 quarters, because dividing 75 by 50 leaves a remainder of 25, just like the starting quarters.<n><n>---<n><n>Input: 4 + 8 = ___     8 - 4 = ___    2 + 2 = ___    4 - 1 = ___<n>Output: You add to get:<n><n>    12<n><n>    The sum of any group of four numbers will always be 12.<n><n>Input: 100 - 100  100 - 80     100 - 40    80 - 80    20 - 80 <n>Output: 80 - 40 is the same as 100 - (100 - 20) which is the same as: 100-100+(100-122) which is the same: 100+20-122. This adds up to: 123. The result from the first problem (7) is the difference from the last, so the answer will be the result of subtracting together the answers to the first and last problems.<n><n>---<n>Input: There are 9 apples in a basket. How many apples did Helen take home? Input: 22 + 8  = ___    12 + 7 = ___    7 - 4 = _____    2 + 4 = _____<n>Output: 22 +8= 30 apples taken home by Helen.<n><n><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/bjUi5.png" alt="Math" width="480" height="250"><n><n><img src="" width="480"" height="250"" alt="Math"><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n>Output:		They are _______.<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Explanation:<n><n>Input: The farmer counted his cows, it turned out that the exact answer was 3 more than his son said. That is, the son said that there were exactly 7 cows in the herd and the farmer counted 10 cows in the herb. The question is which of the following rules applied in the counting?<n><n>1) Add one cow for every 2 that the son counted.<n>2) Subtract 2 cows for every one cow that the son counted. <n>3) Subtract one cow for every 3 that the son counted.   <n>4) Add one cow for the cow that the son does not count.<n><n>Output: The rule applied to the counting is choice 1. Explanation: <n>The farmer counted 1 more than what the son said. From the options that apply to the counting, only choice 1  means farmer counted 1 cow more than what the son counted for 2 cows.<n><a target="new">Click here</a> to download the solution.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n>Output:		The rug must be used under the table since the living room floor would get dirty if there were water spills.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Given code (if input code is false then proceed to next case)<n>Input:The brother called his sister. Her name is Susan. The dog is her pet.<n>Output:Input failed since the brother called his sister Susan or the dog. So, the input code is false.<n><n>---<n># 9.04: Arrays of Numbers<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Create a code for an array a[10]<n><n>### Instruct:<n>The value 5 has a memory address at<n>a[0]<n>a[1]<n>.<n><n>### Input:<n><n>The array contains the following values:<n>1=b<n>2=a and 3=ab<n><n>###Instruct:<n>Input is considered false on the first trial since the value 5 is not assigned to any of the array elements.<n><n>###Output:<n><n>The given array has the following values:<n>a=1<n>b=2<n>c=3 and d=ab<n>e=4 and f=5<n>g=6 and h=7<n>i=8 and j=9<n>k=10 and l=11<n><n>##Instruct:<n><n>On the first trial, the code does not print any values from the array since all values were already initialized to 1 when the code was run.<n><n>On the second trial, a=4 because the value stored at a is initialized to one before the first trial.<n><n>On the third trial, b=3 because the value stored at b is initialized to the value 1 by the first trial.<n>For more information on initialization rules, refer to the Java tutorial.<n><n>On the fourth trial, the code prints all the array elements.<n>##Instruct:Write a code to store the first 15 integers in an array 2[15].Assign the largest element to the first and smallest to 20th position.Print the integers from 1 to 16<n><n>###Input:<n><n>a = 10.<n><n>There are 3, 4, 5 and 6 in the 2[14].<n><n>###Output<n><n>The integers in the array a[10...13] are:<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n>Output:		The correct answer is B.<n>Sometimes you may be asked to find the difference between two numbers.To make this easier, start by finding a number for which the difference is one. Then subtract this number from both numbers with the difference being the one you selected.<n><n>Input: 112÷24.<n>Output: The answer would be 4.7.<n>The output will be rounded by the computer, so it appears as 5.<n><n>Input: A square inch of cardboard covers 12.5 square inches of window screen. How much window screen covers 1 square inch of card board?<n>Output: 12.5 ÷ 12.5 = 1<n>Since 12.5 × 12.5 gives you 156.25, and 12.5 is one-twelfth of the square. The formula will then give you the answer of 1/12 = 1.<n>To find a percent-saving, you must divide a discount by the original price. Because 156.5 is the original price, and 25 is the original discount. 156.00 divided by 156.75 = 0.9775, this is what is given in the percentage.<n><n>Input: Sally, Ben, and Charlie started making pizzas together. Ben and Charlie have to make a pizza in 9 hours, Ben made 1/2 the pizza and Charlie made the rest. How many hours did Sally work?<n>Output: Sally worked one-ninth of the total time. If Sally worked four eight-hour days, she worked eight hours. Then multiply eight by nine, which equals 72. Add one-ninth to this, bringing you to the final answer of 75.<n><n>Inputs: 6000,37.4<n>Outputs: The answer is 160. Which is obtained by finding 37 and dividing it by 60 which is 0.62.<n><n><n>Input: The formula to divide fractions.<n>Output:  x, y = ((x + y) (x ÷ y)) ÷ y.<n>x is 12 and y is 5.<n>((12+5)(12÷5))÷5<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The man tried to run, but he could not. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:There is a lot of sugar in what food that fits in your hand? Choices:  A: cupboard B: chocolate C: coffee D: candy bar E: soda pop<n>Output:		CANDY BAR<n>The correct answer is candy bar.<n><n>Input:A group of teens has $471. How much does each teen have?<n>Output: $471 divided by 5 is $94.20<n>Thus the amount of money that each teen has is $94.90, but they will need to decide for themselves whether to spend it all on a movie, a meal, and a drinks or how to split it up.<n><n>Input: A group of teens has \$471. How <n>Output: \$471 divided <n>By 5 is \$94.20.<n>Thus the amount <n>Of money that each teen <n>Has is \$94.90.  <n>But they will <n>Need to decide for <n>Themselves whether to <n>Spend it all on a <n>Movie a meal <n>And drinks or <n>How to split it up. <n><n>Input: A dog has 10 puppies. How many dogs are there in all?<n>Output The correct answer is dogs.<n>The dog will be a mom and each puppy is a new dog. Mom + puppies have 11 (M + P)<n>When there are as many adults as there are children, each adult is the parent of half of the children. Thus the children are half as many as the adults, so there must be twice as many adults as children.<n><n>Input: If the total amount of money in a bank's safe is $5,900, and each teller has $320, how many tellers does the bank have?<n>Output:There are 3 tellers because the tellers' amount of money is the same as the total money in the bank.<n><n>Input: 48 people arrive at a party at different times during the hour. If each pair of arriving people meets one another, what is the number of total arrivals?<n><n>Output: The correct answer is <n><n>\(\frac{2^n-1}{n^2}\)<n>The pattern for this can be seen from<n>48 = 7 × 7<n>76 = 7 × 11<n>94 = 7 × 9<n>8.256 = (2^(27)
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:A student wants to hear what the professor is saying, what does he do? Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n>Output:		Choice A: In order to gain experience through the class notes, the student needs to focus and listen carefully.<n><n>## 결과<n><n>![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sangyuns1314/sangyuns-algorithm/master/image/inputoutput/inputoutput.png)<n><n>## 기타<n>

The sum of 54 and Janet's number of cards is the same as Brenda's number of cards. How many cards do each of them have?<n>Output: They each have 4 fewer than the sum of their two numbers of cards since the sum of two + two is four less than the sum of the two numbers of cards.. Janet's number = 26 + 4 = << 26+4=22+4>>22 + 4 cards.<n>Brenda's number = 54 + 4 = <<54+4=5+4>>56 + 4 cards. The sum of Janet's cards + Brenda's cards = 82 + 56 = <<82+56=138>>138 cards or one sum + one sum = two sums.<n>So the final anser is 22 + 4 + 56 = \<22+4+56= 82>>82<n><n>### (Solved problem) Example 3:<n><n>Input: Precious

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What does someone need to do to begin creating art? Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n>Output:		To begin creating art, one needs to relax B<<To begin creating art,one needs to relax B>><n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. What was the total number of hours and meters he traveled?<n>Output:The total number of hours he traveled was 16-16 = <<16-16=0>>0.<n>The total number of kilometers traveled in the east  was 7*16 = <<7*16=112>>112.<n>The total number of hours traveled in the west was 16*20 = <<16*20=320>>320.<n>The total distance traveled was 320+112+112 = <<320+121+204=656>>656.<n><n>Input: There are 5 pets in the house. Choice:  A: 3PM  B: 4PM  C: 5PM D: 6PM<n>Output: Choice: (B)<n>There are three choices (A, B, and C) that involve a dog leaving at noon. There is only one dog left, so if none of the dogs left at noon, then the other only one dog can leave at noon. In other words, the remaining dog must leave at 3.<n><n>Input: The first step is to add the two numbers and to subtract the two numbers. For example, lets use the numbers 235 and 172. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n>Output:		Take money for the man was the correct answer.<n>This is because to take "money" out meant to get cash.<n><n>Input:There are 5 cousins with birthdays in the next 2 weeks, What's the day that they will have their parties?<n>1.Amy: Saturday<n>2.Bruce: Sunday<n>3.Maria: Monday<n>4.Chris: Thursday<n>5.Roger: no party<n>Output: Chris (Thursday) birthday<n><n>Input:What day will come next? Choices: 1 Monday 2 Tuesday 3 Wednesday 4Thursday 5 Friday 6 Saturday 7 Sunday<n>If you pick first you pick Sunday.<n><n>Input:Choose the correct pair of consonant digraphs that rhymes: B D G and/or P.<n>Output: The correct answer is B D G (which is BOOK as a word)<n><n>## [223. Countdown](https://leetcode.com/explore/interview/card/top-interview-questions-easy/111/interviews/1170/top-interview?start=23&end=26)<n>

Choices:  A: television B: bus C: email D: web page E: la ville<n>Output:		A: television, B: bus, C: e-mail, D: web page, E: la ville The answer should be<n>A<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Jamie wanted to reduce her waist size, but all of her efforts failed miserably.  She continued to do what? Choices:  A: gain weight B: augment C: dispare D: make larger E: expand<n>Output:		Jamie did all the wrong things <<make larger(B), Dispar(D), Augment>>Augment<n><n><n><n>### Code:<n><n>```python<n>class Solution(object):<n>    def convertTime(self, time):<n>        if time % 60 == 0:<n>            result = 0 + int(time/60)        <n>        else:<n>            result = int(time / 60) % 60 + 1<n>        return result <n><n>    def getFraction(self, N):<n>        """Input: A number N.<n>         Output: A list of 6 numbers. The numbers are 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. The list denotes the digit with which you should multiply N to generate the fraction. The index 0 indicates that it is digit 10 because 10 / 1 = 10.<n>        """<n>        output = []<n>        for i in range(1,6):<n>            result = N // i<n>            if result*10 > N:<n>                output.append(5)<n>            else:<n>                output.insert(0,i)<n>        return output<n><n>    def solve(self, A, B, C, D, E, F):<n>        """ <n>        input: four numbers.<n>        Output: the answer of a maths problem<n>        Method: divide the numbers by each other to get the answer as a result from a math equation.<n>        """<n><n>        result = A // B          <n>        if result*10 == A:<n>            resutl = 0 + 1<n><n><n>        result = result//E // C<n>        if result* 10 ==  A:<n>            result = result // D<n><n><n>        result//F // result // result // result<n>        return 0 + result<n><n><n>    def findTotientNumber(self, N): <n>        """Input: An integer N.<n>        Output : The totient number of N.<n>        Method: start counting from N.<n>        """<n>        <n>        Nmodulus = N % 6 - 1<n>        div = 6 - Nmodulus//self.convertTime(N)<n>        if div == 0:<n>             return Nmodulus<n>        else:<n>             return div
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:John and James spent most of their time communicating with each other on their project. C: progress D: transfer of information E: collaboration<n>Output:		The collaboration or transfer of information took more time.<n><n><n><n>[See Example](https://github.com/Shubham080/CS152-01-21st-Sem-C-Program-Fall-20/blob/master/Week6_C_Program/MultipleChoice/MultipleChoice.cpp)<n><n><n>## Solution: 1.	<n><n>	#include <iostream><n>	/*<n>		TCS-152 Spring-2017 (8)<n>      Problem ID :Multiple Choice [15441]<n>	*/<n>	class multiple{<n>		public:<n>			static int test(int a, int b);<n>			int total(int num1,int num2);<n>		};<n>		int multiple::test(int a,int b){<n>			int  total=0;<n>			total= a*b;<n>			return total;<n>		}<n>		int multiplex::total(int num1,inint num2){<n>			if (num1 > num2){<n>	       }else{<n>	       }<n>		}<n>    #include <ios><n>    using namespace std;<n>    int main(){<n>      int input,output,case=0;<n>      do{<n>	  	cout<<"Choose from 1 to 5: \n";<n>        cin>>input;<n>		case=multiples::total(input/2,input%2);<n>        if (case == 0){<n>        if(input+input%2 > 100){<n><n><n>        }<n>        else{<n>           cout<<(input/2)*(input%2)<<endl;<n>        }<n><n>        }<n>         else{<n>        	cout<<"Invalid Input! Try again\n";<n>        	case = 0;<n><n>         }<n>      }while ((input!= 5)&& (input!= 0)&& (case!= 0));<n>      return 0;<n>    }<n>

This is not a compilation error, but it is an interpretation error. The methods do not need to be declared within the test class. Because the methods are just getting executed to confirm the output, and no need to return a statement. The variables being used within that method is within that class in the same project. Just to avoid compiling errors, we can declare all the methods within the same class.<n>```<n>//Declared the entire methods within the same class<n>public class test {<n>    <n>    //This is the first problem we encountered<n>    //In this Problem, Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda.<n>    //Marla has twice as many cards than Janet.<n>    //How many cards do they have all if Mara has -150 less than 15<n>    //Janet has 9 more than it so she has 9 cards more in all.<n>    //Mara has twice as many so she has 16 = 24 more cards than Janet<n>    //and then the last problem says that in general Mara has 16 more cards in all.<n>    public static int testOne(){<n>        System.out.print("Input: Janet has more cards than Brenda ");<n>        System.out.print("Input: Mara has twice as the number of cards than Janet ");<n>        System. out.print("Input: How many cards do they  have in all if Maraa  has less than 15 than 150 cards ");<n><n>        System.out .print("Output: Mara has (150 - 15 ) = <<150 - 34 = 116>>116 cards  ");<n>        System.  out.print("Janet has (116/2 = <<16*2=78>>78 cards since Mara has the same number of cards than Mara");<n>        System. out.print("Output: Brenda has (78  -  9 ) = <<78 - 9 = 69>>68 cards since Janet has the same the

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n>Output:		The correct answer was A: demonstration, which was the best guess based on the words my and what.<n><n>Input: How long does it take a car to travel a distance of 1 mile at a constant speed? A: 180 minutes<n>B: 1,800 seconds<n>B: 5 minutes<n>C: 100 miles<n>Output: A mile equals 1760 yards, so 1 mile is traveled in <<1mile/60=17.6>>17.6 seconds. Then one hour = 60 minutes, so <<60*60=3,600>>3600 seconds. 1 mile / 60 = 17.6 seconds, and 17.6 / 3,600 = 0.005 seconds. This is 0.0000005 seconds, or 0.00(5) seconds. 0.00 (5) is equal to <<1/1,000,000>>1/100000, which is <<0.0001>>0.0003. The answer to choice D is 0.03 seconds. So the final answer is 0.09 seconds<n><n>Input: Three months ago, the month was two months from Christmas. How many months have passed since Christmas?<n>Output: Three months ago was (4 months + 2 months - 2 months) = **10** months, and since Christmas was two months from Christmas, there were 4 months before Christmas, and 4 months after Christmas, or 8 months total past Christmas. Two months ago, there as 10 months passed, and today, there are 8 months past Christmas, meaning 44 months, or <<3600*44=156,000>>(156,040) total months after Christmas. So, the final answer is 156,060 months.<n><n>Input: You add 15 apples to a bushel of apples. You end up with <<2B + 315>>315 more apples in your bushel. How many apples did you start with?<n>Output: You started off with 1 bushel, so there were 50 app

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n>Output:		The East coast areas of Florida are from area A. <n>The easternmost regions of the continental U.S.<n><n>Input: A group of 5 friends and 7 teachers met at the playground. There were a total of <<5+7=12>>12 people at a playground. Do you want to play?<n>Output: <<12 is a prime number.12 is prime.>>12 is a prime.<n><<5+7=14>>14 is the sum of 5 and 7.<n>There were <<14-5=9>>9 people not at the playground. Then there were <<9+7=16>>16 people at the playground since 16 is 2 more than 14.<n><n>Input: If you count every letter, the word TEN has 10 letters, but if you just use the initial letters, the word for ten in Spanish has <<2-1=1>>1 fewer letter.<n>In the word TEN, all of the letters except for the letter T are not repeated, so <<11*(10-1)=111>>111 ÷ <<100>>100 = 1.1.<n>If you count every letter, this <<11*10=110+1=121>>121 so that <<1+1=2>>2.1 times 10 = 2.<n>One + one equals two, so <<10+1=2,1000>>21000 ÷ <<10^2>>102 = 21000.<n>Thus, the answer is 2100<n><n>In English, the abbreviation for miles is "m." In mathematics, it is defined like this: <<1/mile=1/60 of a mile=1/60*mi=1/3600 miles>>1/360<n>1 mile = <<1000/3600=2/5ths of a mile>>2/5ths.<n>0.002 times a mile = <<10/360*1000=0.00284>>0.002<n>0.0000284 miles = <<284/10
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What could listening to music cause you to be? Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n>Output:		F The correct answer is "B."<n><n>### Instruction:Write a python program to read the input, based on your understanding of the instructions, and print the output to the screen. <n>''' <n>     Example: <n>     Input:  Pete walked 5 block from his house to the <n>     post office to get some <n>     stamps. <n>     Later, he came home <n>     the same way. <n>     How many block did Pete <n>     travel in all?<n>     Output: 25<n><n>'''<n>

Choices: 1) 36 days 2) 46 days 3) 56 days 4) 66 days 5) 76 days<n>Output:46. Day of week: 1 = Monday 2 = Tuesday 3 = Wednesday 4 = Thursday 5 = Friday 6 = Saturday 7 = Sunday<n>Input:How many dogs can a person own legally in the US? Choices: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6<n>Output:4. No state requires four or more to get a state license or extra fee: 1 - Alabama, 2 - Florida 3 - Utah 4 - Tennessee 5 - Georgia 6 - Delaware<n>Input:Rebecca has two couches, two lamps, three recliners and a coffee table. She has two sets of six plates, two sets of eight placemats, and a set of 8 cups. She also has one toaster, two microwaves, three blankets, and one television. How many pieces of furniture does Rebecca have in all?<n>Output 255<n>Input:Amy has three quarters, a dime and seven pennies. How many different ways can she make change for a dollar?<n>Output:Eight. Because quarter, dime, and penny all go to 1,1, and 100 respectively.<n>Input:How many 2x2 and 5x5 squares fit in a 6x6 grid?<n>Output:2. 5x5 will fit, only if 6x6 can fit 3.6x6 will fit with empty cells<n><n>Input:How many different ways can 100 be grouped into groups of 4,3,2,1? Choices: 3) 402544937250<n>How many different ways can you arrange 6, 4, and 2 in such a manner that no digit is repeated in each line?<n>Output: 2.<n>You can arrange 6 and 2 any way you like, they are not the same.<n>Four and 4 also work. Three and 2 works. 6, 4 and 2
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n>Output:		Further cause of leaving has insulting them<n><n>*Input:Further<n>Output:Cause<n><n>*Input:Pick<n>Output:A<n><n>*Input:Which<n>Output:B
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n>Output:		The correct answer is _<<A>>_ since they cant die but they die.<n><n>Input:A rectangle with an area of 60 square meters needs to be painted using 120 meters of paint. How much paint per square meter is that? Choices: 4:1 A: B C: D E: C<n>Output: The answer is E with a 4:1 ratio. The amount of paint per square meter is 4 times larger than the area of the rectangular. Since the rectangle has an area of 6, dividing it by 12 gives 6/12 and multiplying it by 12 again gives 6*12=72. 72 divided by 6 gives 12 and 12 divided by 4 gives 3, so 3 is twice as big as 1. Since there is an even amount of paint available the solution is <n>(3/2)6 = <<3/2*6=18>> since there is also a 1:2 ratio going from meters to square meters. <n><n><n><n>Input:There are 22 students in the class. 9 students do not want to go to the dance. If 42 students go to the dance, what is the minimum number in any group of students at the dance?<n>Output: the correct answer is C << 9/22 = 4/11>> because it must be a whole number, but any other numbers can go to the dance if they want to.<n>#1<n>### Instruction:<n><n>For the first question, answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>Input: Janine is the oldest child in her family. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:If an animal is tired, what is it likely to do? Choices:  A : to change in shape or size  B: to become better or more effective  C: to change the amount of or how often you do something  D: to start from one place and return to it  E: to say less than the rest of something, such as your friends or family  F: to have a bad or bad-tempered face  G: to not happen on time (or in the time period that is planned)  H: to give more money or have a higher number<n>Output: The meaning of a is correct, and the meanings of B, C, D, G, and H are incorrect. Choices:  A: radio station B: recording studio C: concert D: tv studio E: new york<n>Output:		The answer is D. For radio station, the boom mic is not used to record. The final answer is option B. A recording studio, the booms are commonly used.<n><n>Input: Which of these numbers are prime numbers Choices :  A: 10 B: 12 C: 20 D: 30 E: 50 F: 110 G: 130 H: 150 I: 178 J: 199 K: 262 L: 270 M: 345 N: 466 O: 595 P: 987 Q: 1000 R: 1100 S: 1200 T: 1300<n>Output: G can be eliminated because the prime factors of 1000 are 2, 5, 1000 G is even, while 471 is odd and thus cannot be prime. The answer is A or D based on a comparison of the prime factors for the respective numbers.<n><n>I hope you enjoyed this post and that you gained at least one new thing that you didn’t know before. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n>Output:		Bob thought that they were personal.<n>So the answer is Personal<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n>Output:		The old man liked to do each crossword puzzle because it was mentally challenging. He did not care about his age or how long it took him. However, he was not bored, relaxed, passing time, or merely winning.<n>So the final  answer is  mentally challenged<n><n>Input: Which of the following words has the most letters?  Choices:  A. Restaurant  B.  Museum  C. Theater  D. Cafe  E. Theater 1. Restaurant 2. Museum 3. Theater 4. Cafe 5. Theater<n>Output: The word theater has the most letters. It has 11 letters. Restaurant has 10 letters, and museum has 8. <n>Cafe has 7 letters, and Theater 1 has 5. So the final answer is  Theater 1.<n><n>Input: A train left from San Francisco, CA 94104. The final destination is New York, NY 10001 traveling at an average speed of 50mph. How many hours will it take to reach the final destination? Choices: 3 hours 6 hours 8 hours 10 hours 12 hours<n>Output: The final answer is 10 hours.<n><n><n>Input:  One of the four numbers is 342.  What is the other three? Choices: 1. 602, 479, 81, 342 2. 81, 602,479,342 3. 479,602, 342, 81 4. 342,81, 615,479 5. 81,602,342,479<n>Output:  The third and fourth numbers are also the first two numbers. The numbers are: 602,81,479,479.<n>Therefore, the number is 602, also 479. <n><n>Input: If 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are positive numbers, each representing at least one digit of the answer of a problem, then what is the next number in the sequence? 14 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve? Choices:  A: ruined B: clean clothes C: sadness D: attractive appearance E: look better<n>Output:		A>>A>>A>>A>>The man was looking to achieve Clean clothes for his date<n>Input:Which is faster, a fast horse or a fast car? Choices: A: the fast horse B: the fast car C: a speeding car D: the fast horse E:the fast car <n>Output: The correct answer is A. When the fast horse is going at a fast speed, that's the fast horse.<n>When the fast car is going at a fast spped, he is said to be speeding, which we say as a speeding car. This is not the fast car in the meaning of A.<n>Also, when the fast horse is going, he is a fast horse.<n>But when the fast car is going, it is a speeding car, when speed is used.<n>We are talking about when the car is going fast, it is a speed in the same meaning. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Hence after watching a movie, if you drink Soda, then you would go to do other activities. That means the final answer is Option D: reading Reviews<n><n>Input:Which of the two numbers is larger, 11 or 7?<n>Output:<n>You have both the numbers: 11 and 7.<n>Subtract both numbers: 11 - 7 = <<11-7=4>>4<n>Add the two numbers: 11+7=<<11+7=18>>18<n>Thus, the final answer is 18<n><n>Input: Which of the two numbers is greater, 4 or 32?<n>Output:<n>There are 32 possible answers in this question. Hence, answer 32 is correct and not answer 4.<n><n>Input: When is Christmas?<n>Output: Christmas is on December 25th.<n><n>Input:How do you get to work?<n>Output: Get a car!<n><n>Input:While playing tic tac toe, how do you make a row?<n>Output: Horizontally<n><n>Input: How do you spell "Mary"?<n>Output: M-A-R-Y<n><n>Input: Mary wrote the words "Mary is good". ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:I'm at a restaurant ans want a glass of milk, how do I find out if they serve that? Choices:  A: accompaniment to meal B: waitress C: cafeteria D: home E: menu<n>Output:		To find out if restaurants sell milk, ask the waitress.<n>The answer would be A.<n><n>### Instruction:Code the above sentences using IF-ELSE statements.<n><n>In my first attempt, I've made a loop of if-else statements: <n><n>```python<n>d=[1,2,3,4,5]<n><n>result=0<n><n>n=0<n>print (d[n]=0<n><n>n=n+1<n>if n==len(d):<n>    result=0<n>else:<n>    a=0<n>if a==1:<n>    result+=1<n>else:<n>    b=0<n>if b==2:<n>    result+=2<n>else:<n>    c=0<n>if c==3:<n>    result+=3<n>else:<n>    d=0<n>if d==4:<n>    result+=4<n>    pass<n>else:<n>    e=0<n>if e==5:<n>    result+=5<n>else:<n>    f=0<n>if f==6:<n>    result+=6<n>else:<n>    g=0<n>if g==7:<n>    result+=7<n>else:<n>    h=0<n>if h==8:<n>    result+=8<n>else:<n>    i=0<n>if i==9:<n>    result+=9<n>else:<n>    j=0<n>if j==10:<n>    result+=0<n>else:<n>if i==10:<n>     f=0<n>if j is not equal to 2:<n>    result=1<n>else:<n>     result=2 <n>```<n><n>But in my second attempt, I use a function to calculate the answer:<n><n>```python<n>def mult_arr(arr):<n>    result=1  <n>    for n in arr:<n>        if n==0:<n>            result+=1<n>        else:<n>            result+=n<n>    return result<n>```<n><n>In my third attempt, I use a for-index-statement for a single answer:<n><n>```<n>d=[2,2,2,2]<n>for i in d:<n>    result+=i<n>print (result)<n>```<n>### Instruction and Question:Answer the following multiple-choice problem.<n><n>Input: "I’ve got $30 worth of items in my shopping cart." <n><n>Choices
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What could happen after driving car that does not involve pain? Choices:  A: automobile accidents B: backache C: eye strain D: getting tired E: car crash<n>Output:		The answer is b<<A+B+C+D+E=car crash>>car crash.

Choices:  A: growing older B: reproducing C: shuddering D: perspiration E: palpitations<n>Output:		If you are growing older, you are not likely to live soon, and an answer is B=<<B=reproducing>>.<n>If you are reproducing, you are likely to live soon, since reproduction is a sign of youthfulness and energy that is necessary for your survival, and an answer is A=<<A=growing older>>.<n>If you have palpitation, you are probably living soon.<n>So, if you have none, you are living very soon.<n><n>Input:How do you put out a kitchen fire?<n>Output:Choices:<n>  1. Remove the smoking material and turn off the heat source. 2. Use a blanket, towel, or damp cloth to mop up the remaining fire. 3. Use a fire extinguisher, if one is available. 4. Don't try to fight the fire alone if your efforts increase the risk of injury.<n>Since the most preferred choice is 1 and the second choice is 2 which is not preferred.<n>So the total score for putting out a kitchen fire is 3.0/4 where 3.0 = 1 + 2 and 4 is the total number of choices. So final answer is 3.0<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:What is a great, but non-specific, overall benefit of exercise? Choices:  A: good health B: heart attacks C: relaxation D: rest E: fatigue<n>Output:		Exercise will benefit you in many ways, not just a few. You will benefit by being in good physical and mental health and by gaining strength, energy, strength, agility, and balance. These benefits will reduce the chances of heart attacks and stroke, prevent premature osteoporosis, reduce fatigue, help control weight, and help you rest. So the final answer is D.<n><n>Input:What are the most common forms of diabetes? Choices: 1: auto-immunemic, or Type 2, that occurs most often in young people 2: Type 2, occurs in older people, mostly women 3: A: Type 2, and B: Type 2, both occur in younger people.<n>Output: Type one is a diabetic condition that occurs in young people who cannot metabolize sugar because they have not enough insulin. Type two has low amounts of insulin that the body cannot produce. It affects older people, mainly women in their 40s. So the final answer for 1, Type one, and Type two, is the first option or type 1 and 2.<n><n>--->[[Back | [[Next page]]]]<---><n>

The 4th choice should be removed for all of the remaining choices.<n>E. rooster is the correct answer. It means the correct answer is after the choices. The 4th<n>choice should be the first choice and all other choices (excluding  E) should be after E.<n>G. early riser is the exception. The correct answer is not at the end, but at the beginning of the statements.<n><n>1. the 3rd choice: it got too warm so its wasted (which means 2nd choice is correct answer).<n><n>2. the 5th choice: pumpkin rots (which means 6th choice is the correct answer).<n><n>3. the first choice: it is too warm (which means it was rotten and it is wasted).<n><n>4. the 8th choice: put on porch<n><n>5. the 10th choice: rotted and it is wasted (which means rotted and placed on porch)<n>```<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question correctly using these statements.<n><n>The pumpkin was picked it was picked from the patch the pumpkin

So the final answer is town.<n><n>Input: How many more girls are in the class than boys?<n>Output: The class has <<42>>42 girls and <<28>>28 boys. So each girl is <<42/28=1>>1 more than a boy. They have eaten each member of the family <<1/5>>1/5 pies for <<2/5>>1/10 days. The members of the family have eaten the pies for <<1/10+1/15+1/8 + 1/5+1/25>>2/25 or 3/25 days. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Where would you put a light? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n>Output:		The answers for the choices are A: ocean/desk/chair B: universe C: attic D: none of the above<n><n>## Multiple Choice Questions Solution<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the multiple choices question.<n>Input:Janet has 9 cards <n>more than brenda.Mara has twice as many cards <n>as Janet.How many cards do they <n>have in all if Mara <n>has 40 cards less <n>than 150?Output:Mara has 150 – 40 = <n><<150-4=110>> 110 cards.Janet <n>has 110/ 2 = <n><<110/2> = 55>> 55 cards <n>since Mara <n>has twice as many as <n>Janet.Brenda <n>has 55 – 9 = <n><<55-9 = 46>> 46 cards <n>since Janet <n>has 9 cards more than <n>Brenda.Therefore, <n>they all have <n>110 + <n>55 + <n>46 = <<150+55>> 116 <n>cards.<n>So the final <n>answer is 116<n><n>Input:Pete walked 5 blocks <n>from his house to the bus <n>garage in Houston. He <n>rode the bus 20 <n>blocks to the post <n>office to get some <n>stamps.Later, he came <n>home the same way. <n>How many blocks did Pete <n>travel in all?Output:The number of blocks <n>traveled on the way <n>to the post office was <n>5 + 20= <<5+20 = 25>> 25.Pete <n>traveled 25 xx 2= <<25 x2>=- 50 blocks in all<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the questions that follow.<n><n>####Instructive questions:<n>-   A: ocean B:desk C:universe D:attic E:chair<n>-   A:desk,ocean,chair  B:ocean,desk,chair  C:the best choice  D:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:The priest pushed for more orthodox behavior, what kind of behavior was he trying to stop? Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n>Output:		B: heretical<n>So the answer is B<n><n>Input:If you say "Jane's hat," who do you mean? Choices: A: Bob B: Jane C: Sally D: Sally E: Jane<n>Output:A: Bob<n>So the answer is A<n><n>Input:A new software to predict heart attack has only been in the market for one year. Based on the data collected so far, it seems likely that this will become the most commonly used software by the dentist to prevent heart attacks. Choices:  A) True B) False<n>Output:False<n>So the answer is False<n><n>Input:Molly and Pete are both 29 years old. Pete is 3 years older than Molly. Choices:  a) Molly is 26 years old, or b) Molly is 31 years old<n>Output:Molly is 26 years<n>So the answer is Choice (a)<n>Input: A = 1, B = 2, C = 3, D = 4, E = 5. For each letter, list the four numbers before and after that letter. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>So the final answer is 50<n><n>Input:Where would a Martian find the Indian Ocean? Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n>Output:		Answer: C<n>Input:How long ago did cavemen hunt mastodons? Answer: A: 50,000 B: 10,000 C: 1,000 D: 500 E: 1,024 years<n>Output:Answer: B<n>Input:Mrs Brown makes 11 pancakes. She gives 6 to her son John who eats them all. How many does she have left?<n>Output:Answer: E<n>Input:What time did a clock read on September 13, 1998?	  A: 6 am	  B: 7 am  C: 8 am  D: 9 am  E: 10 am<n>Output:Answer: A<n>Input:What does 0111 = 5 in number base notation?<n>Answer: A: 7 	  B: 8 	  C: 10 	  D: 13 	  E: 14<n>Output:Answer: D<n>Input:What is the rule for dividing numbers, called the "divid- ing" rule? A:  B:  C:  D: <n>Output:Answer: CD

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices: A: Jack has two, Harry has one B: Jack has four apples, Harry has five C: Jack has eight apples, Harry has nine D: Jack has exactly nine apples, Harry has three<n>Output: Jack has nine apples, Harry six.<n><n>Input: Daisy buys 4 oranges. She has 4 quarters. How much change does she receive? Choices:  D: 100 cents B: 0<n>Output: She receives 25 cents since the cost of one orange is 25 cents. So the number of quarters = 4<n>Number of quarters that can be found in one orange = 25%<n>Number of quarters left when one orange is bought are 4 × 25% = <<4*25%=100% >>>100%.<n>Now 100 of quarters left when Daisy buys one orange. That means that there are = (4 × 25%) = <<(4*25%=)<<(4*12.5%)>>12.5% quarters left after buying 4 oranges (since 400+5 = 450).<n>So the change Daisy receives after buying 4 apples is 12.5%(450) = <<5%(45)>>3<n>As a result, Daisy receives 30 cents of change<n><n>Input: Choices:  A B C D<n>Output: There are no pairs of numbers that are in the same position with different properties.<n><n>Input: A and B are related by subtraction.
